i finally got it. if you have coordination/cogitative issues, pause the video at 0:51 and set the video playback speed to .25. go grab some silverware from you kitchen as your drumsticks and keep replaying it in slo-mo over and over again once you have the beat in your head. i recommend starting with the right hand and getting that tempo down first. then work in the foot. once you have those two beats down consistently, introduce the left hand because i feel that is the hardest.

i think people who can play drums, even just the basics, take for granted just how much coordination it takes. it's a lot more complicated than it looks. i've been playing on and off since i was a kid, and i'm mostly self-taught. i have dyspraxia (developmental coordination disorder), and it took me so long to pick it up as my brain couldn't isolate all of the separate parts. drumming has been great for my coordination, even though it takes me a bit longer than some people to learn beats.

start with just the hi-hat to establish your rhythm. then add either one of the drums, then the other. keep that hi-hat tap going, though. you can practice just tapping on a table. use two different parts of the hand; one sharp, like a knuckle or fingertip, and a softer, thud sound, like the palm for the bass.

these days, we're lucky because there are so many options for quiet (or even silent) practice on the market. lots of compact options, too. they aren't all cheap, but some are fairly inexpensive. and, of course, the most economical option a practice pad takes up almost no space at all, so it's a win/win!

if you have an interest in giving drums a try, you can find an option that will work for you!

thanks for watching and commenting! no pressure but we made 30-day drummer with domino for people in your situation. it's an easy way to get started drumming with even just a practice pad and sticks (you can get a full bundle plus the lessons for $117 right now).

watching the gears turn is enjoyable. such a simple beat looks and sounds so easy, but the ability to separate your limbs is the challenge. the rub your head pat your stomach thing.

i had about 2 years worth of learning and playing the electronic organ, and some years later in high school the teacher in the music class was having us try all the different instruments. i was surprised to find that my previous experience with the electronic organ had trained my brain to be able to play the simple beats but nothing complex.
i am always amazed at how excellent drummers make all things look so easy and simple.
so much harder than it looks.

harder than one would think

i've never really given it much thought since i've been playing since high school, but i guess people really do have a tough time separating their limbs. for drummers it's not something we give much thought to
